sentence.content: It&apost;s been more than a year since NBA legend Shaquille O&apost;Neal retired from the court, and he says he doesn&apost;t miss it.
The basketball champ has his eye on a new target: diabetes.
"It&apost;s alarming," says O&apost;Neal.
"We need to come together to try to help prevent the disease and stay healthy."
Nearly 26 million Americans have diabetes, and another 79 million Americans are considered pre-diabetic, according to the American Diabetes Association.
Approximately two thirds of diabetics eventually die from heart disease or a stroke.
For O&apost;Neal, the fight against diabetes is personal.
He was drawn to finding a solution after watching close family members struggle to manage the disease.
He&apost;s now focusing his energy on preventing people from developing diabetes in the first place.
"Childhood obesity is getting worse," he says.
"People need to know the problem isn&apost;t going to go away unless we take control now."
O&apost;Neal spent years taking flak about his fluctuating weight throughout his 19-year NBA career.
But the self-proclaimed "freak of nature" says there&apost;s always been a method to his madness.

"[Critics] would automatically say, &apost;He&apost;s out of shape,&apost; but I wanted to just relax during the summer, hang out with the family, and then work my way into basketball-playing shape," says O&apost;Neal.
"I&apost;ve never been obese.
Even now my body fat is only 13%."
Today, the 7-foot tall O&apost;Neal says his current weight stays around 350, "plus 10," but admits it&apost;s not easy to stay at a healthy weight and reduce his risk of developing diabetes.
O&apost;Neal says he limits the amount of carbohydrates in his diet, eats a salad for lunch everyday and only indulges in an occasional brownie, his vice.
He also clocks one hour of cardiovascular activity each day.
"It&apost;s a different world we live in now," says O&apost;Neal.
"I always urge people to eat healthy and ask them to try to help your kids get exercise.
I stress the importance of keeping them in shape.
It&apost;s not about the physical appearance but for their health."
In addition to raising awareness on how to prevent diabetes through a healthy lifestyle, O&apost;Neal says he also wants to help diabetics better manage their disease.
He recently invested in a product called glucose quick sticks, which he describes as a healthier alternative for diabetics when their blood sugar is low.
